conclusion: Analyzing the p-V diagram and using ideal gas laws to determine temperature at state C.
State A: p = 3×10⁵ Pa, V = 1×10⁻³ m³; State B: p = 1×10⁵ Pa, V = 1×10⁻³ m³; State C: p = 1×10⁵ Pa, V = 3×10⁻³ m³.
Temperature at state A is 27°C = 300 K (converting to Kelvin).
Using the ideal gas law: PV = nRT, where n and R are constant for this gas sample.
Establish the relationship between states: P₁V₁/T₁ = P₂V₂/T₂.
Find temperature at state C using state A as reference: T_C = (P_C V_C / P_A V_A) × T_A.
From A to B: Isothermal decrease in pressure (volume constant); From B to C: Isobaric increase in volume (pressure constant).
For an isobaric process (B to C), V_B/T_B = V_C/T_C.
Find T_B from A to B (constant volume): T_B = (P_B/P_A) × T_A = 100 K.
Calculate T_C for B to C: T_C = (V_C/V_B) × T_B = 300 K.
Revisit analysis to trace the whole path from A to C properly.
A to B: Constant volume process (isochoric) where pressure drops from 3×10⁵ Pa to 1×10⁵ Pa; B to C: Constant pressure process (isobaric) where volume increases from 1×10⁻³ m³ to 3×10⁻³ m³.
For the isochoric process A→B: T_B = (P_B/P_A) × T_A = 100 K.
For the isobaric process B→C: T_C = (V_C/V_B) × T_B = 300 K.
